number of helpful: 263 of 282 people (93%) found this review helpful12 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												I FIXED IT!To everyone that keeps saying that Uplay crashes and that you can't play this is what you need to do:1) Uninstall the game and Uplay (AKA Ubisoft Launcher)2) Install Uplay from Ubisoft's site.3) Login with your account (on Uplay) and make sure you're online.3.1) There is an option to activate game, choose it.3.2) Copy the game's activation code to it (the one Steam provides you)3.3) It will ask you if you want to activate From Dust to that account, choose yes.4) In Uplay, choose "Go Offline", and that's it (but don't close Uplay).6) Install the game on Steam and playNote: In Uplay's settings I recommend that you choose "Always start Offline" and disable any synchronization to Uplay (specially the save files), because it is absolute garbage, you should also disable overlay.For those wondering, the problem is the interaction between Steam and Uplay, and the fix is launching (and installing) Uplay by itself instead of letting Steam do it.The game itself is a lot of fun, it sucks that Ubisoft had to ruin it, I would recommend the game, but not the company.

number of helpful: 173 of 203 people (85%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												TL;DR, I highly, highly recommend playing this game, but I do not recommend buying it. This is one of the coolest concepts I have ever seen destroyed by an unusable DRM scheme.From Dust is a work of art. Watching the form of the earth change and mould as the player manipulates it brings back memories of Black and White, but with a sense of visual awe that comes from being a much more recent game. It is something that I feel any gamer owes it to themselves to experience at least once. Sadly, I can't recommend buying the game, as I have an ethical objection to UPlay. The alternative, a Chrome app that is free in the Chrome Store, is okay, but ultimately Ubisoft's disingenuity has ruined, or at least limited access to, what I consider to be an actual art piece.Fun fact: Ubisoft actually patched the game to remove UPlay. I had been hoping that would happen and bought it shortly after. Only a few months later, I had been happily enjoying my new game when I launched one day to find UPlay had been patched back in.Ubisoft, I know you're not listening, but stop punishing your customers for buying your products. You did the right thing once before and removed the DRM from this game. Now that the DRM is back on, I would not be surprised to find the number of seeders for this game on torrent sites has spiked. No one wants a content management system inside another content management system, especially if they only have one or two games in the "nested" one.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2013
												From Dust is a creative and interesting god-game/strategy game. It's sort of an update on Populous. Way better looking than Populous, though.I enjoyed playing From Dust through about half of the game's missions. Figuring out how to manipulate the environment to advance your tribe through a series of goals is fun and challenging. But after about 5 levels, the game's challenge became less about figuring out a strategy, and more about executing it with the awkward controller scheme. After about 8-10 levels, it just became too awkward to play. The strategy elements of the game outgrew their clumsy control scheme.I might recommend this, though, if it's on deep sale. It's pretty to look at, and I had a good couple of hours of fun before deciding the juice wasn't worth the squeeze. ...That damned level with the burning trees. Gah.

content:
Posted: January 23
												The Steam version of From Dust runs just fine without Uplay. If that's the only thing preventing you from buying it, then don't let it keep you from experiencing what is a very unique and enjoyable strategy game.It will only take you 5 minutes, at most, to create a firewall rule so that From Dust will run just like any other non-Uplay Steam game. You don't need a Ubisoft account either, and you can play in offline mode.After downloading From Dust, but before starting it for the first time, install Ubisoft Game Launcher from the From Dust\Support\Ubisoft directory. Then use Windows Firewall to block the Ubisoft launcher from using the internet, which will prevent it from updating to Uplay when you start the game.That's all you need to do. If you aren't familiar with how to use Windows Firewall, there is a short guide that will show you how to create a rule for From Dust right here: 


How to play From Dust on Steam without Uplay 
A Guide for From Dust
By: ThreeSon

			You don't need Uplay, a Ubisoft account, or an internet connection to play From Dust on Steam.

number of helpful: 58 of 90 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												First of all this game will require Uplay to play and you will have to lock your serial to that one account so don't forget the information. While annoying, this is doable and not the only game like it. Wish I had read more of the steam reviews before buying. I would not recommend this game and if you already bought it, my sympathies, but it is not the next Black and White. Buy at own risk, I cannot stress this enough.Controls and Mechanics: Saw a lot of complaints about this. Some buttons are counter intuitive or not 'the norm' but you can grow accustomed to them fairly quickly there's only two really weird ones. UI is spare so you aren't overwhelmed with options. Movement of the cursor corresponds with the movement of your avatar and 90% of the time this is fine and you get used to it fast. The other 10% of the time it will go too far too fast or something at just the wrong time and Bad Things will happen because of it (this has caused me to restart at least one map). Similarly 1-2-3-4 isn't hard to remember, but when the powers attributed to them shift around you have to constantly check the menu to make sure you're using the right power.The AI of the people is actually fairly decent - when it works. When it doesn't you get dozens of annoying little voices screaming at you from the top of a hastily erected pillar as rivers of lava flow around them, voices which you cannot stop until either that lava does, or one of your powers comes up, etc. Furthermore idiotic people have cost me wins before, causing me to have to restart some maps several times or making simple tasks very hard. Camera: Similar to dungeon crawlers, up above and slightly behind the avatar with the option to zoom in a little or to zoom in completely (and not be able to do anything) on just one of your humans. Like the controls 90% of the time this is fine, but when it goes wrong it can be very frustrating giving the fast liquids you are working with.Now to the reason I am writing this review: some spoilers ahead (I try not to name names). Surprisingly interesting premise and I genuinely wanted to see my people through and to find out more about what had happened before me. The cut scene between maps gets annoying overtime since its pretty long and just the same footage over and over again but that's not game breaking. What is game breaking is the end. The last level. First of all the game froze just as I was about to complete it so I had to go back and do it all over again (first time this had happened). I hesitate to detail what exactly happens but suffice to say that I was extraordinarily displeased, felt that absolutely NONE of the plot points were tied up (they didn't even try to softball something in or if they did it was too subtle for my shock and disappointment to see it), we weren't given any revelations or massive info dumps, its one giant screw you to the idiot stupid enough to waste their time on this game. Before the end I was willing to give this game a pass and say there were some levels worth redoing, some content worth getting every little bit from, but afterwards I uninstalled the game without second thoughts.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												From Dust is a fun physics game that won't keep you coming back again and again to play it, but luckily the technology itself has aged well. What other game has free-flowing water, sand, and lava that can all be mixed together to create rock, land, volcanoes, mountains, earthquakes, and tsunamis? If you are hoping that the very end of the game unlocks a no-strings-attached sandbox mode, however, you may be slightly disappointed. The sandbox mode that you get at the end is another level where you get to use all the abilities you gain across the rest of the game to beat the level. After you beat it, you return to the main menu. From there you can choose to play it again, but it doesn't feel at all like a truly free sandbox mode. If you can get past that, then I would recommend this game simply so you can playing with water, sand, and lava.

number of helpful: 30 of 42 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												I don't play a lot of "God games" but for me From Dust was fresh and different. Tasked with guiding a primitive tribe on a quest for answers about their past you are given control of the environment, picking up dirt, water, and lava, to clear paths or build them, while fighting off nature itself.Visually From Dust is appealing with beautiful tropical islands to arid deserts and lava crusted mountains. The way your powers mold the environment also looks very good. The campaign is just about the right length with a lot of extra content in challenges or open worlds if you're craving more in the end.For the most part everything works as expected. Occasionally you will drown or burn some of your people but almost always it's because of your own mistake. That being said, occasionally the AI has some pathing issues that lead them into unnecessary danger and get them killed. More common though is having trouble telling where the AI will allow you to go, mostly involving how steep a slope they will walk up. This can cause problems when you think you have a clear path but the AI refuses to move and reverts to complaining about how much they are now on fire. It was never bad enough for me to make me stop playing though.From Dust is a nice change of scenery and play style that is definitely worth your time.

Posted: October 12, 2014
												From Dust has been repeatedly misidentified as a "God" game, which it is not. It is more accurately described as a terraforming puzzle game, and a very good one at that, managing the ideal puzzle game balance of simple, intuitive mechanics that are extended across a substantial breadth and depth of scenarios. It's one crippling drawback is the horrid, controller-developed control scheme, although this is manageable and somewhat forgivable.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												Once you get past Uplay, and I did swear at the screen many times during this process, this is a good game.I wouldn't call it a 'God' game. There's no morality choices, no true growth of a civilization, and you’re the only ‘god’ around. It’s you against nature, in a series of puzzles to test your growing powers. It doesn’t take long to make your way through the puzzles, and while there’s a sandbox mode in there as well. It didn’t really hold my attention. Expect 5- 10hrs Gameplay, depending on how fast you like puzzles.All considered, it's physics engine is beautiful, the gameplay is simple but fulfilling, and if you get angry you can wall up your little guys and let them slowly drown beneath the growing tide.Once again, Ubisoft is a pain, Uplay is stupid. But if that’s the biggest downside; it must be a decent game.

number of helpful: 12 of 18 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												An amazing adventure, magical humble little game that puts you into role of a god that guides mysterious tribe on journey to discovery through the power of terraforming. Every mission is essantially a puzzle to solve and with increasing difficulty it results into about 10 hours of top notch entertainment. Some people throwing temper tantrums because of the uplay, I had no problems with it at all (I never had uplay crashing or anything those guys are "experiencing"). The important thing is that a review that only lists problems with uplay is not a review of this game at all. The game is an overlooked gem, it has amazing aesthetics and so much charm most of the other titles would be envious. It's not a groundbreaking title, as this was done before, but it's done really well.Two reasonable criticisms - mouse controls are not that good, and while your villagers aren't exactly lemmings, they can be pretty dumb. Neither of those are serious issues and will only take a few moments to get used to it.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												From Dust is a brilliantly done, wholly unique... gosh what to even call it? RTS? Eh, I dunno about that. Simulator? Kinda?  You get to play as a god that shifts the terrain of a planet in order to benefit your people. That's what you do; I don't know what to call that kind of game, but I guess that's my bad.  Anyway, it's not only a gorgeous game but it's so well crafted in mechanics, character, and just overall design that I cannot recommend it enough. It's a game that challenges you, but does so in what seems like a nonthreatening way so your motivation as a player feels very organic and unforced. The soundtrack is jawdropping, and helps to draw you into the world like nothing else. In short, for those who want an immersive, unique take on the sim/RTS franchise, pick up From Dust. You will not be disappointed.

												The Uplay issue has long since been fixed! The game is perfectly playable from Steam.Now I got this game to fill the void left behind Black and White. There just hasn't been a god game to equal it despite it's flaws. This could have been a worthy successor, though it may be a little too eccentric for some players.I like the tribal setting, its not something we get to see very often in games and it gives this game its unique sense of identity. It starts to lose its edge however as most of the game is manipulating the enviroment in very puzzle like ways, to get your little tribe from point A to point B. There's really not that much more than can be said. It's seems addicting, but it's no Black and White. Unfortantly it got tedious fast. I just can't in good concience recommend it.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												While this is a recommendation in favor of From Dust, it comes with a lot of qualifiers. This is not a game that is worth full price. Yes, the graphics and production value are above average. And yes, this is a well designed God Game. And yes, because of the dynamic way in which the world behaves in reaction to your choices can drastically change the playthrough of any particular level. And ultimately yes, the levels (what few there are) are well designed.But that brings me to my first complaint: There are only 12 levels (not counting the finale which doesn't really count since you can easily win simply by not using anything but the Breath of Earth.) For a full priced game, this is scaled more as a tech demo and paying full price is outrageous. (And I mean that to be a bit dramatic, because Fromt Dust is offensively short.)It took me roughly 6 hours to beat the game (And I had to play at least three maps over.)Which leads me to my next complaint:  There are no saves. If you fail, you have to start over from the beginning of the level. That's not horrible, but it is made painful by the unskippable cutscenes and monologues at the beginning of each level. If you're not beating the level in the first or second try, the tedium of unskippable cutscenes is likely to drive you slightly mad. The cutscenes are "cute" the first time through, but after that they start to grate on your nerves. Your followers don't speak English. Everything is subtitled. While this seems like a novel idea at the beginning, people speaking gibberish at you on the start of each level (coupled with the fact that you cannot bypass it) quickly becomes annoying. This annoyance is mercifully mitigated by the short "single player campaign." (Of questionable value, since it also means there isn't much meat on the bones of this game.)My third complaint is that it requires Uplay, Ubisoft's DRM. Ubisoft's DRM is draconian. There are multiple features in many games that simply do not work if you do not have an active internet connection (as opposed to Steam, where that connection is only required on first activation.) Additionally, Uplay fails to install correctly when installed through Steam and you have to jury rig it to work (I put a guide together under From Dust for anyone who buys this and runs in to the installation problem and goes looking for the solution.) While Ubisoft has removed some of the other unpalatable elements of Uplay DRM, it still remains the poster child for "what not to do" among game producers.However, if you catch this on a sale ($5-10 tops) and you can tolerate dealing with Uplay, you will find yourself faced with a few (very few) enjoyable hours with Fromt Dust.The gameplay that derives from wielding god powers (water, warth, fire and life-- no air here) is enjoyable. The sense of urgency that derives from the interaction between floods and earth washing away, or between a lava flow steadily working its way into your followers-- these interactions are compelling and interesting.Unlike Molyneux's "God Game Remake in Godus" there is no farmville experience here. You really are left solely with Godly concerns. How do you unlock your next power?, how do you expand your followers across the world in the face of looming environmental disaster?, how do you help them escape the world before the tenuous balance you've maintained comes crashing down around you and your followers?The story is nothing special. It starts as a question, and it ends as a question.The graphics are pretty spectacular (for what it is). There's not a ton of individualized follower behavior (You typically zoom all the way out and do your best to stay on top of the floods, or the tsunamis, or the volcanos  that are poised to end your followers.) But the environmental effects are pretty interesting. Water that is volumetric and looks like water. It has waves, it feeds plant life, it cools lava. Lava that is equally volumetric, and which cools when it thins, leaving behind a layered rock strata on which the next wave of lava will rise over it. Each river, be it water or lava, is unique and behaves according to physics which seem realistic (so long as you don't analyze them too heavily.)The game performs well (one crash of the game, one crash of Uplay before I applied the installation fix I mentioned earlier). The audio is well designed, if a bit shallow and repetative. The digeridoo sounds are thematic and interesting (but if you don't like them, they become fairly constant in late game and that is likely to get on your nerves.)All in all, despite its many flaws, I would give From Dust a positive rating-- at a much lower price point.If you happen to see this on sale and feel like a few hours with a novel take on the God game genre, then give this a try. (But don't get it except on sale, because there just isn't much under the hood to justify the cash expenditure.)

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												This game honestly has to go down as one of my top 10 games. People that are looking for a Black and White clone this isn't it. Its a sandbox physics game and I found it highly addictive. The water physics are amazing and I have never seen a game with water this advanced. Basically each level is a puzzle (think Lemmings if you will) where you have to get your tribes people to the exit by claiming all the different sites around the map. Once this is done the exit will open and you can lead them to it. Obviously its not that easy as tsunamis, fires and even erupting volcanoes try to stop your progress. You can manipulate the water, lava, sand etc to help you along the way as well as being able to restart the map if you feel you f'd up because you wanted to see what happened if you diverted that river into that volcano..Sad for the people that had issues in the past with the DRM/Uplay stuff but it looks like Steam has changed that now and for me I was able to open the game right from Steam without any issue.For the hours of fun and cheap price of £7 I would have to give this 9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8
												This is a beautiful sandbox game in that it is literally like playing in the sand. I bought it on sale, and for whatever it cost me (maybe $10) it is one of by happiest gaming hours/$ spent. I got about 10 hours out of it at this point and am very satisfied.Visuals:Totally great. Sure, they could be better, but I loved getting down to the tribe's viewpoint and watching the tidal waves come, or the water rise. So neet.Challenge:Not too hard, but kept me on my toes even on low difficulty on the later levels. YMMV.Replay:The game is really attractive, and the challenges of each level ensured that I played each level through at least twice. However, beyond this once-or-twice level replay I did not feel the urge to replay. Partilly this is because on many levels while there are multiple ways to get through the challenges, but usually there is a clear optimal one. I know I'll pick it up in a few months and enjoy it again, once I have forgotten some of the tricks though. Imagination inspiring:Just amazing. If you ever played in the sandbox as a kid, or built sand castles on the beach, check this out. Some of the less obvious strategies can be fun to at least try!Uplay/copy protect:Whatever system other people have their legitimate complaints about... it didn't effect me. Maybe there was an overhaul of the system? It did not affect me in the slightest, so I consider this issue resolved. Note, I played on steam/pc.

If you're after a resource management style sim game you'll have to look elsewhere.From Dust plays like a very stylized physics puzzle game and is tremendously nice to look at, to boot. Admittedly I mostly grabbed the game because it was Eric Chahi's return to gaming, and I was interested in what he had to offer. The man certainly hasn't lost his touch - while I feel the game's concept certainly could have been taken further, it does what it sets out to do pretty well.

All of my Ubisoft games, including From Dust, are now totally inaccessible. Fortunately I didn't have many of them, they have not made many games I thought might be worth money. From Dust, one of the few exceptions, was a flimsy puzzle game not worthy to raise and lower the land under Populus' sandals. I do not care if Ubisoft never fix this, from now on they can shove their games up their DRM-loving jacksies.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Controlling the power of good and evil.....no, wait....this is not Black & White. From Dust is not about training a creature and fighting other gods. It combines some elements of Populous and B&W but it is very unique in it's own way.The game is set in an extreme version of planet earth. Being a god, you must protect your tribe against the powers of nature by manipulating the world with sand, water and lava. Help your people to survive and expand. Besides the campaign, you can play several time-based challenges.Eric Chahi and his team created an intense god simulation game with a marvelous physics engine, a great contribution to a genre, which is unfortunately very rare and inconspicuous.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Don't let the beautiful pictures on the Steam shop page blind you; this is -in 9 of 10 cases- not what you'll actually see while playing the game. I'm not saying that the graphics of From Dust were ugly, they are not. But you watch the world from high in the air, and the tiny people of this world are just that: tiny, tiny people. But that's not the problem of the game. I admit, I was hoping for a modern version of "Populous". A proper God-simulation. But your powers as a God in this game are highly limited. Everything in this game is highly limited. Your tiny people have to discover or populate around certain obelisks before you can work wonders. Those "wonders" allow you to manipulate the world to a degree. I'd say 80% of the play time, you pick up sand and drop it somewhere else. This way you create land for your tiny people, or you dig ravines for controlling the flow of waters. It's actually quite fun for a while, but pretty soon it gets old. You are doing pretty much the same all the time. From Dust clearly is not the new Populous. The old hit from 1989 beats From Dust in the categories fun, length and complexity. The world of From Dust provides only roughly one dozen maps, and those are not really huge. Between the maps you watch the same boring sequences again and again, you do the same things again and again, move tons of sand from A to B so that after some settling you can get your tiny people to make it to the exit of the world. Maybe that's why we only got a dozen or so maps (of which the first few are pretty much meant as tutorial maps...), because the developers realized that the game concept is simply not complex and entertaining enough to motivate for more than 10 or so hours. French games are often pearls of innovation and creativity, but this one sadly, is not.

Posted: August 18, 2011
												From Dust is possibly one of those games you play that turn out to be just as good as game with tripple it's price tag.The game is classed as a Godgam & Semi-sandbox. You play a sperm, i mean something called 'The Breath' and the main goal is to spread your people around different lands avoiiding dangers that harm your people. Like God verstion of lemminigs so to speak.The physics in the game is beyond anything i have seen, water moves so realstic i was busy creating waves to notice my Tribe burning to crisp. There are 12 levels and one more that is you create your own land. You may clock in 7 hours on your fist playthough. Plus lots of possible replay value. 												From Dust is a very interesting game.First of all for an indi game, the graphics and the physics are overdosed with awesomeness. Posted: May 8, 2016
												This game is very creatively made. It's not one of those games where theres just one way to solve a problem and you have to find it; rather, you are given tools to shape the environment that cause gradual butterfly effects that are sometimes not what you expected and no two soltions will be exactly alike because the environment is constantly changing and adjusting in response to your actions. This creative platform tickled me a lot; I've never seen another game quite like this. Some levels were challenging and frustrating but satisfying in the end; others were a little easy but over all it was well balanced. It was a joy to see what creative challenge came up next each time. My only complaint is that the game is short -- I would love to see more! Also its replayability is limited. I'd definitely recommend it if you are looking for something different and/or short and sweet.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2011
												From Dust presents an interesting way to sculp the Earth, though with a poorly made PC port.In From Dust, you control villagers like in Populous. You can manipulate earth, water, and lava to reach village points and to reach the next level. The goal is to find out where these villagers came from. As levels progress they start in island places with lots of water, next to big volcanoes, or in a stretch of dry desert. The villagers have a unique appearance to them, along with their art and music being of unique looks. Controlling matter is easy and the land and water physics is handled very well. These points add for a special experience.The problem lies with the later PC release. As this was made for consoles it wasn't well optimized. Ubisoft requires to use their DLC along with Steam just to use it. The performance is abysmal, but the art and music are sure to please. While the game has a unique artistic and realistcally amazing design, the PC framework just doesn't do justice.

Posted: March 4, 2016
												This is a pretty decent and fun god game where you get to help a tribe of people regain their lost knowledge and grow as a civilization but due to the constant crashes and glitches I have trouble recommending it. You take on the form of a deity known as the breath and have been bestowed the power to absorb and spit out the various elements of the land water and earth. Using this you can form land bridges or small lakes to help your tribe survive; it is a lot of fun.This game is a good game but the port has something to be desired. I managed to play it through to completion a few years ago but even then it crashed repeatedly and now it is almost unplayable. If you can put up with the technical problems or are lucky and don’t have any then this is a real gem and worth playing but if not then I wouldn’t recommend it.Oh and Uplay... enough said.Have fun ːMMForFunː

Posted: April 17
												Predstavte si, že ste niečim, ako boh a máte vo svojich rukách osudy primitívnej populácie v období, kedy ľudské pôsobenie na zemi ešte len začína. V tomto originálnom koncepte realtimovej stratégie sa doslova môžete zahrávať so životmi praludí a to ničím menším, ako rovno zosielaním skázy formou prírodných živlov. Sledovať malé postavičky snažiace sa bezmocne úkryt pred obrovským množstvom valiacej sa vody, či na opačnom konci rozmáhajúcej sa žeravej lávy, je vážne zábava. Vašou úlohou je ale životy nič netušiacich primitívov previesť cez všetky nemilé prírodné katastrofy a zachrániť tak našu civilizáciu pred neštastným osudom, aký postihol vyhynutých dinosaurov. Dostanete do rúk vlastne sandboxové pieskovisko, do ktorého sa Vám nikto babrať nebude a zostava len na vás, ako jednotlive úlohy splníte. Je potrebné priviesť malé postavičky praľudí na druhý breh silnej rieky? Môžete sa pokúsiť pritekajúcu vodu zastaviť pieskom vytvorením hrádze. Púštny piesok ale silný prúd vody nemusí vždy udržať a skôr či neskôr prerazí a vaši zverenci skončia v dejinách vyhynutých tvorov. Čo tak ale nasmerovať lávu z neďalekej sopky priamo k rieke? Ta potom prudkým ochladením vodou začne náhle meniť svoje skupenstvo a razom mame základ pre pevnú hrádzu, ktorá divokú rieku ďalej nepustí. Lenže ona rieka stále priteká a naša premyslená lávova hrádza nemá neobmedzenú výšku. Voda časom začne pretekať a svojou neúprosnou silou zastihne nič netušiacich praľudí snažiacich sa po novovzniknutej cestičke prejsť na druhu stranu, bez akejkoľvek šance na útek. Logika by v takom prípade našepkávala docieliť nejakým spôsobom menší prítok vody k hrádzi, aby nezačala pretekať. Pripadne sa len snažiť spomaliť tento jav na dostatočne dlhu dobu, aby bolo možné osadenstvo neďalekej dedinky bezpečne previesť k novým zážitkom. Opäť máte niekoľko možnosti, ako toho docieliť. Jednou z nich je časť valiacej sa vody presmerovať vytvorením provizórneho koryta v piesku a odviesť tak určite množstvo nechceného živlu inam. Teraz už naši spokojní zverenci môžu bezpečne prejsť na druhý breh rieky a spoznať tak opäť další kút našej budúcej zeme. Takýchto rôznorodých úloh budete plniť veľa a neustále a bude len na vás, ako s ďalšou a ďalšou výzvou popasujete. Časom ale cela hra skĺzne do opakujúcich sa postupov a prestane ponúkať nové možnosti skôr, než si budete sami želať. Stáva sa tak postupom času mierne stereotypnou záležitosťou, ktorej až príliš skoro začne dochádzať dych. Tento koncept hratelnosti je ale tak iný a tak unikátny, že nedoporučiť tých pár hodín nenahraditeľnej zábavy, by bolo snáď ešte väčším hriechom, ako svojou nerozvážnosťou zapríčiniť vyhynutie našej rasy predčasne.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												The game works fine and has interesting game mechanics, primarily the control of natural elements like fire, lava etc. but the novelty of the levels wear off and it just doesn't feel like an accomplishment when you finish a level. I was left more infuriated at the lackluster controls, which seem like they were made for controllers not a mouse, and the repetitive nature of the game. There are challenge modes aside from the main missions but there is no definite "zing" with anything this game does (aside from the awesome sound and ambient music). It seems more like an experiment than a full-fledged game. This was definitely originally intended for console gaming and not PC. You'd do well to watch some gameplay videos before going for a purchase and even then I'd recommend waiting for a sale. Also, UPLAY DRM ALERT!! Functional, but shallow and uninteresting.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												A rather short game but fun all the way down. It is as fascinating to watch as it is to play. The fantastic idea gives you the power of being the protective creator of a tribal group of people by modelling nature and landscapes. Even if the main action of piling up and excavating the level's territory may not sound spectacular, I already played it through several times. Not least this is due to the physics which grant sensible effects from all my godlike actions. You have the power over lava, earth and water with which you can shape the landscape in favour of the tribe. The goal is to create a save passage over the map to some ruins which grant access to the next scenario. In this sandbox nature is your persistent opponent. If you are not careful fire burns your village down or flood washes your people away.A real downside of this game is the story. Actually there is no notable plot which could be called a storyline. Other than the campaign you can also play in custom empty map where you can build your own landscapes.It has also to be stated, that the game requires UPlay since it is an Ubisoft game.So it is a game that is different. Unfortunately it is not complete, neither by its extent nor by its plot. Nontheless, it reminded me as well of endless hours in the sandpit during childhood. Not least thanks to the still pretty graphics I recommend this terraforming god game.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Going in, I was a bit intimidated by "From Dust." I was worried that I'd get overwhelmed by a complex, totally freeform sort of experience where deep mastery is required to have any fun at all.I'm pleased to say that this title avoids that problem. You're generally allowed to ease into the mechanics quite gently, and you also tend to get a lot of warning about things potentially getting away from you. Thoughts like "Oh...what I'm doing with this volcano won't be very helpful in a minute" are much more common than "What the heck just happened?" Your goals are easy to identify, and mistakes are usually correctable. Even when you completely fail, you can usually see where things went wrong.I also felt that the general mysteriousness of the game world was highly compelling when combined with what you do find out. It all left me wishing that I could have discovered more regarding the goings-on.It's true that the behaviors of the people you're trying to help can be a bit less than helpful, especially given their tendency to be finicky about where they can and can't go. (There's also the whole problem of them managing to drown in something like one foot of water.) Even so, the quirks aren't so bad as to ruin the game."From Dust" is a slightly quirky but ultimately interesting ride. I think it's worth trying.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												Installed this again to see if Uplay/Steam is broken as some say. (Oct 2016)Answer is nope, installed, autoupdated, started,, no problems at all.Feel bad for ppl with all the problems, but it's not broken and worth a bad review based on that imo.But Uplay being Uplay I'm not really surprised there's problems around, but it's Uplay in this case that should get the thumbs down,,not Dust.With that said.It's a fairly short game with a bit (sometimes) clunky controls.And it totally lacks setting for graphics. But that's ok, it looks fine on it's own.But I really like this one, it's giving me flashbacks to Black and White and I loved those games.Mold the earth to your liking, help natives get from point A to B. Be a nice "God" and put out that fire, build a brige,or not.Grab a fist full of lava and dump it on that villager that's been eyeballing you last week?,, it's all good.I like to play around in the game, rather then just do this,,and done, game lasts longer if nothing else ^^For me it's a game I'll return to now and then and play a bit, just for fun.For 10€ you get your moneys worth, at least i think so.

Posted: March 12, 2014
												I played this game on console, and I bought it for Steam the instant it went on sale. Not because it's not worth the money, but because it was the second time I was purchasing it. (well, and it's short, so buying on sale is probably the better bet for that reason as well) This god-style puzzle game is just gorgeous. A beautiful, atmospheric, absorbing and utterly enjoyable game that will captivate you while offering progressively more difficult tasks to advance your tribe through the various stages of their evolution. The interface is intuitive, the puzzles are sophisticated and yet gentle in their difficulty curve - but there is DEFINITELY a curve, they will get tricky - and the story while fairly barebones is one that gives you some cause to get attached to these little guys as they deal with the struggles ahead of them. I have not had to use mouse and keyboard on the later puzzles of course, but I could see where you might prefer a controller - it's definitely a comfortable and pleasant experience on the console. I strongly recommend this game!Fair warning: This game requires Uplay to use - if you don't want to deal with the Ubisoft DRM system, then this is probably not the game for you.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Going in, I was a bit intimidated by "From Dust." I was worried that I'd get overwhelmed by a complex, totally freeform sort of experience where deep mastery is required to have any fun at all.I'm pleased to say that this title avoids that problem. You're generally allowed to ease into the mechanics quite gently, and you also tend to get a lot of warning about things potentially getting away from you. Thoughts like "Oh...what I'm doing with this volcano won't be very helpful in a minute" are much more common than "What the heck just happened?" Your goals are easy to identify, and mistakes are usually correctable. Even when you completely fail, you can usually see where things went wrong.I also felt that the general mysteriousness of the game world was highly compelling when combined with what you do find out. It all left me wishing that I could have discovered more regarding the goings-on.It's true that the behaviors of the people you're trying to help can be a bit less than helpful, especially given their tendency to be finicky about where they can and can't go. (There's also the whole problem of them managing to drown in something like one foot of water.) Even so, the quirks aren't so bad as to ruin the game."From Dust" is a slightly quirky but ultimately interesting ride. I think it's worth trying.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Really awesome until the last few levels. Before the later stages, it was relaxing, like playing in a sandbox, yet reasonably challenging without being frustrating or punishing. Unfortunately, as I got to the later stages, difficulty arose due to a certain totem being placed in a very tricky, high and near-lava location. You have to rely on the individual pathing of the AI, but there's not much indication if they'll be able to get up slopes (when there's multiple potential routes to a location) so trying to get them to this totem without having them try to cross lava is an exercise in frustration. The AI pathing tends to be annoying to deal with as the stages get harder. Also, depending on how you may have tried to build walls in stages with lava, you may find yourself having spent a lot of time on a stage but in a sitation where you'll have to try to destroy some walls to let your villagers get to a totem. Doing this is tedious because you need to use explosive plants (if you made rock walls). I don't understand the point in letting players manipulate something in such a tedious way instead of providing a less time-consuming method.Overall, dealing with the lava is quite frustrating, especially with how it can completely wipe out villages if so much as a particle touches some of your greenery. I understand having a challenge makes things more fun, but the way this challenge is presented is more frustrating than entertaining, because a small mistake can reset your entire stage progress. Slight variation on the level design and the lava mechanics would've probably made the game fun, but as it is I can't recommend it because of the unpleasantness of the later levels. Challenge should not come from dealing with the stupid AI, and mistakes shouldn't make you feel like you've just wasted a bunch of time, because that's no fun. Towards the end it just became not pleasant to play anymore. It's a shame because the sandbox mechanics are very entertaining to interact with - it's almost like they weren't sure whether they wanted to frustrate players with hard challenges or provide a relaxing, slow-paced sandbox game.

Posted: November 16, 2015
												For  short game, it is a decent amount of fun. This is a fun sandbox game that gives you an objective, but you can complete it at anytime and in any way that you would like. I spent a lot of time playing the demo on my Xbox 360, and I really enjoyed it, so I decided to finally get the game for my computer. The AI is decent at path finding, but can get irritating at times with them getting stuck going up a hill when they could much more easily go around. The gameplay changes from stage to stage, adding a new element for each stage. I enjoy that they do this. Diversity really helps this game. I think I may be getting to the end of the game, which is disappointing, but there are challenge modes to tackle after you have completed the main story. Final note: Wait for this game to go on sale if you are interested in playing it.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												NOTHING LIKE POPULOUSThis isn't a god-game, not in that sense. You're a god, sure. With powers over nature, sure. You lead a tribe of people, sure. But this is really a puzzle game. You move dirt and lava and stuff around to make a way for your people to reach new village spots. That's it. Oh and there's no real progression between levels. If that sounds fun, have at it.I expected more, and I guess that's my fault for not reading enough reviews.BUT, the mouse controls suck. I'm four levels in and I still hate how the mouse controls. I regularly pick up water instead of the dirt I want that's next to it. Directing my people to a new spot is hard because getting the mouse to settle on that spot is hard. There's some really weird acceleration going on. And the game forces me to use uPlay. Despite my admission that I shouldn't have bought this game, I think this paragraph still warrants a thumbs down, because I tried to enjoy it for what it is and these frustrations stopped that.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2012
												It's like a smaller scale Black & White, without a giant animal. The goal is to guide your tribe to the right place(s) while protecting them from natural disasters. This can be done by changing the environments. So, for example, you can create walls to protect them from lava or you can create a hole in the ground to keep the water in. It's all up to you, as long as you can protect them. But it gets challenging pretty fast.The graphics are pretty sweet, especially for a downloadable game. It definitely has a nice style. The sounds are very well done as well.All in all, it's a game I would recommend. There aren't that many 'God sim' games around these days, so From Dust is a great addition to anyone's collection.[Rating: 77/100]

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I'd recommend this game but with a couple of major reservations.First off the good.I think the core mechanics are neat and well executed. Moving terrain around and using it to affect the lives of the indigenous population is great fun. The fun for me at least partially stems from my sense of nostalgia of playing in the backyard and digging out villages for my populations of action figures to live in. Also, I have a weak spot for games in which physics manipulation is the basis of the mechanics.Now for the badFirst off screw uPlay. This game somehow got deleted from my uPlay account so now I can only play it in offline mode. However I can't inherently judge the game for that failure, just Ubisoft's publishing policies. Buyer beware, I guess.Second, it feels like a console port. There's minimal graphics options. The controls are awkward and become a hindrance on the later, faster paced levels. The menus are unpolished and make it a pain to navigate between level selection and other important features.In conclusion I liked this game but there are some major issues with it's packaging. If From Dust was remade or they made a sequel that controlled better, operated better on the PC environment, and didn’t include mandatory uPlay integration, then I would definitely be able to recommend it.

												Okay I played From Dust a while ago on my Xbox and fell in love with  it and now that I've gotten into PC gaming I was so excited to see that there was a PC version. I highly reccomend it to anyone who loves god games HOWEVER. In order to get it to even run I had to delete the Ubisoft launcher files from my computer and then go onto the Ubisoft website and download the Uplay launcher from there. Now it actually works. So I do actually reccomend the game, but bear in mind that you will need to do a bit of finangling to get it to work, but the game is totally worth it!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I'd recommend this game but with a couple of major reservations.First off the good.I think the core mechanics are neat and well executed. Moving terrain around and using it to affect the lives of the indigenous population is great fun. The fun for me at least partially stems from my sense of nostalgia of playing in the backyard and digging out villages for my populations of action figures to live in. Also, I have a weak spot for games in which physics manipulation is the basis of the mechanics.Now for the badFirst off screw uPlay. This game somehow got deleted from my uPlay account so now I can only play it in offline mode. However I can't inherently judge the game for that failure, just Ubisoft's publishing policies. Buyer beware, I guess.Second, it feels like a console port. There's minimal graphics options. The controls are awkward and become a hindrance on the later, faster paced levels. The menus are unpolished and make it a pain to navigate between level selection and other important features.In conclusion I liked this game but there are some major issues with it's packaging. If From Dust was remade or they made a sequel that controlled better, operated better on the PC environment, and didn’t include mandatory uPlay integration, then I would definitely be able to recommend it.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												It's a shame the store page shows mixed reviews in red, this game is fantastic! It's not super long or deep, but it is a well paced, well balanced, terraforming and water physics based puzzle game, with a sandbox mode to boot. It looks incredible, and is extremely good fun and damn satisfying. It plays much better with a controller (or at least it did at release, I can't say for now), but most people's complaints are purely about uPlay, which really isn't THAT bad, and certainly not a REASON to NOT get a great game, at least it is AVAILABLE on Steam unlike anything by EA these days!

content:
Posted: August 20, 2011
												This game is a bit deceptive in it's marketing. It looks like an immersive RTS where you manage a tribe and develop them into a civiliazation whilst avoiding the plagues of nature.... But realistically it's just a puzzle game where you try to get villagers with no story, personality, individuality, or unique characteristics whatsoever from point A to point B utilizing a physics based, fully manipulatable environment.The game: You build sand castles and bridges, try to keep the water and lava out. No enemies, no plot, no advancement, just different levels with different scenario puzzles.Yes it's kind of fun, but not a great game, it could have been a lot better, like Black & White was.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												I have the PC version and after playing 5-6 worlds, I simply couldn't stomach anymore. It was too difficult getting the movement to work with mouse and keyboard. The controller version might be better, but the PC controls and camera are really bad.I also felt the worlds began to become very repetitive. The gimmicks differs between the worlds, but in the end you either move sand/water/lava to rescue your villagers and put the water/lave/sand somewhere else to block the hazard that controls the current world.I never felt like a 'god', more like a janitor.I don't mind using Uplay, but this game does seem to have a problem with Uplay. After I set my Uplay client to start in offline mode and play 'From Dust' in offline mode, the problems disappeared and I could play the game.

												In order to enjoy this game, you must give it some time at first. This is a God game where you can manipulate elemants, you manipulate these elemants in order to get your tribe settled to a village. I would have to say that this game has fantastic replayability due to the fact that you can finish a level differantly each time you play it.The description of the game I've given in the review is a very basic description, give this game a try yourself, you must see the beauty this game has to offer with it's stunning visuals. content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Even though I personally like this game, I will try to stay as objective as I can.I am recommending this game because there is nothing like this out there and it is worth experiencing. BUTThere are lots of CONS:-	Game is super short.-	The controls are unfriendly.-	Can’t skip scenes.-	No depth, no challenge.-	Only thing worth seeing is the physics.Seems that this game was a let’s-release-a-game-with-cool-physics” but nothing else. It is a lot of fun to play with the elements and see how you can affect the world. But that’s it.As far as all the negative comments concerning UPlay: ignore them. UPlay is UPlay, and From Dust is From Dust.  Even if UPlay were so bad (entering a key and logging in, not a hate-trigger for me), they are two completely unrelated things. So, if the game is on sale and you enjoy god-like games, physics/cause-effect, give it a go. I personally felt like “is that it?” at the end. So expect that if you like these sort of games.But still, the concept is good and this is the only game out there where you can manipulate the world like this, and it’s fun. So + for me.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												I bought this game a few years back and I enjoyed it for a while.Every now and again I look at it in my games library and think "That might be fun for a bit", so I start it up and remember why I'll never play it again.Ubisoft Uplay... that horrible invasive DRM... From Dust is infected with it, ruining the entire game. Ubisoft will tell you that it's okay, now the game is patched, you can play offline and never expeirience a breakout or interruption. What they don't tell you is you must keep Uplay installed and authenticate all the time. The last time I signed in after a long absence "From Dust" was no longer in my games library on Uplay... as much as I enjoyed the game it simply wasn't worth the time and frustration for me to deal with Ubisoft to fix it.Until you can trust Ubisoft to release a copy of From Dust without UPlay AT ALL... it simply isn't worth your time.

												It's a fun toy for playing with fluid dynamics and it has a couple interesting puzzles in its levels, but it overall lasts only an afternoon or two's worth of time. It can last longer if you REALLY like playing with the tools it gives you, especially on the unlockable sandbox, but at the time of writing this the game is over three and a half years old and is still the price it was at launch, which was too high then. If this goes on sale for $5 it's an easy purchase as long as you go in thinking of it like a toy  instead of a game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I love this game. It has fantastic atmosphere and it just looks and feels great. It is a story that is not directly put in words or told to you. It is an experience. A journey.You act as a god of a tribe assisting them in their search for their ancestors. The gameplay is really interesting and is based entirely on modifying the terrain in various ways and it works really well. The gameplay revolves around grabbing materials and objects and moving them elsewhere. It sounds boring when described but it very satisfying in-game.There are also tsunamis that cover the entire map, and spontaneous volcanoes to mess up your finely tuned plans. Sometimes the game gets seriously difficult. I remember trying to beat a few levels for several hours.The graphics are stunning and it has good replayability. I've played the game through twice and it's really easy to pick up waste a few hours every once in a while. After you beat the game you unlock a sandbox mode where you can create your own small world. (So much fun!)It seems that Steam did not record all those hours (~40) I've played this game.----[Rating weighted based on the genre]----Story: 4/5Gameplay: 4/5Challenge: 4/5Discovery: 3/5Replayability: 4/5Aesthetics: 5/5Visuals: 5/5Atmosphere: 4/5Music: -/5 (I don't remember it well enough to rate.)

content:
Posted: July 10, 2013
												While it may look like a god game on first glance the mechanics of it remind me very much of puzzle games. You control "The Breath" which allows you to manipulate earth, water and lava and do all sorts of crazy elemental stuff, but it all boils down to getting the tribe people to the next village and protecting them from other elemental forces like tsunamis and volcanoes. It's puzzle solving rather than world building.It might not be the god game you're looking for but it's still fun and worth a try.

												Note: I am in no way in support nor in favor of these 3rd party DRMs. (U-Play)Okay with that out of the way, I managed to work around the so called U-Play and was able to play the game just fine. All you P-ussies whining about how U-Play is♥♥♥♥♥♥is stuff should not call yourselves a true gamer. A true gamer will work their♥♥♥♥♥off and do whatever it takes in order to play that game. A true gamer fear no obsticle. A true gamer always finds a way.Anywho... "From Dust" is a pretty decent and well-rounded god-sim game where you use your powers to help guild the villages to where you want them to go. It's a bit old but graphics are still pretty nice even for an old game. The game is as simple as it can be and is really well done.8/10 Nice game but Maybe wait for a sale.

Posted: April 21, 2013
												Didn't take long to beat, but by far one of the best games I have played, You are god, trying to save tribal people who worship you, saving them from destruction. This game is a bit puzzle, godmode, and just fantastic animations and graphics. I highly recommend buying this game.

Posted: February 2, 2012
												This short game will have you hooked for a long time. Guide your villagers through their world , as their God you will learn to control the elements to expand thir territory . The real star of this game is the amazing physics . If there is water in the way , build a passage by moving earth from another part of the world and marvel as the water parts . Is lava troubling you ? Why not surround it with a lake or use water trees to control the flow of molten rock.Although the game is only about 15 maps long but you will find yourself replaying them over and over just for the sheer fun of it.

Posted: November 21, 2015
												Excellent and challenging non-violent game. You must figure out how to provide for your tribe and how to lead it across various terrains  and avoid numerous environmental dangers. Requires analytical skill in order to access best way to get the job done. Play gets progressively harder as different dangers from land, sea and plants appear. You must settle new villages next to the totems in order to unlock new powers for your avatar.  Lead your people across the land following the path of the ancients while gaining power and abilities. Non-violent and age appropriated for the entire family.

												Very fun in it's own right, very amazing gameplay but a story you won't even notice. The main story tries to fit in between levels and in bits that aren't shown as you play. The gameplay is amazing with water/lava/sand physics to make you♥♥♥♥♥that are just flawless. Really strategic the more you play and the power ups are never explained more past just what they're called and you have to figure out what some do by using them which is fine. You have no real enemies except the elements, but the villagers are a pain in what they accept as a path to walk on and a small amount of water can stop a village to be built. Lava never wants to build as much as it should and seems to just flatten what you put it on. Natural disasters are mainly just annoying but if left unchecked will destroy you. Still a great buy for it's fun value but nothing on replayability.

Posted: August 22, 2011
												What's the matter, villagers? Can't you pick up lava? I CAN. :DFrom Dust is a God-Game in the same style as Black & White, only without the annoying "Oh, your creature just ate half your village. Oops," bit. You control "The Breath", a god-like being with the power to pick up dirt, water, and the LIFE BLOOD OF THE MOUNTAINS. It's your job to protect "The Men", a sort of tribal people with spiffy masks.The world in this game is FANTASTIC. Water flows realisticly and wipes villages off the map. Dirt piles up and settles just like if you were a kid playing at the beach. Lava cools into rock when it's not setting fire to everything ever.The AI is a bit crap, though. Many's the time I've created a safe path from one village to another, only for the villagers to take a path right toward the river of molten rock, and THEN proceed to complain until I redirect the flow. But, it's not so bad that it breaks the game.tl;dr, buy the game, it's fun. Cave Johnson, we're done here.

Posted: March 30, 2014
												This game is easily a good time killer but watch out for losing site of your priorities having fun with the sand and water mechanics. I spent a lot of time making pools and lakes and making them drain from one place to another for pure entertainment even though it was not my objective. Basically you have to get your tribe memembers  from point to another to create small villages, make sure the land becomes lush with greens, and finally getting them safely to an exit. You use your powers as a god to take control of the elements to change the very shape of the land your tibe member are currently inhabiting. Pick up and drop sand to make a crude land bridge or drop water on some vegitation which has caught fire due to the constant lava flow from an active volcano or have your tribe members grab totems to protect you from raging a tsunami. There are intricate ways the game dev make use the landscape and element mechanics to insure getting your tribe memembers to saftey will not be easy.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												From Dust is a gorgeous game with an interesting concept of playing god and encouraging the growth of your tribe as it recovers its memories and re-establishes itself.  The controls are a bit difficult to get a grasp on at first but are easy to use once you have the hang of it.  The game itself is visually stunning with detailed shots of the landscape and your tribe.  However, the game has been difficult to play for longer than bursts of ten or fifteen minutes without those same beautiful visuals slowing and eventually freezing my computer until the game shuts down or has to reboot.  My computer has never had these kinds of problems with games before and I am usually patient enough that if I can get a good amount of play time in then I don't mind.  From Dust, however, shuts down too frequently to really do much in a playing session.

												This game is a great experience, I think that's what it is.It's not the game of the year. But it's really something new, the control scheme is a bit akward, sometimes you have to play with your camera a lot because YOU ARE and your camera is tied to you. So yeah it can be slightly frustrating in a couple of levels however it's all part of the design.This game is not difficult at all, this game is a refreshing experience, a new way to see god games.  Two third god game, one third puzzle game maybe. 7/10 worth buyingNB: I see some people talking about problems with Uplay. No issues over here and you can play offline.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												From Dust is a god game, but not in the way that you might think. Instead of leading a civilization into expansion, you're instead trying to guide them through the world, "fighting" against the forces of nature themselves.Tech-wise, the game looks gorgeous, and more importantly has this fantastic physics system in which fluid and dust settle realistically. This is important, because those are what you'll manipulate most of the time, be it to open a path, to let forest spread, to stop fires, whatever is needed. It's an experience unlike any other game out there.However, as much as I like it, I have to say that it's best to pick up the console versions. For a very simple reason, the PC one brings the uPlay DRM, a highly incompetent piece of software developed by Ubi that has a 50/50 chance of denying you the game you just bought. Myself, I had to spend just under an hour tinkering and watching "update" bars fill up before the game worked. Even if it was worth the trouble in the end, this sort of abuse with your honest customers is simply ridiculous.If you do want to pick it up on PC anyways, good luck, and have a pad ready. K&M controls here are a love-or-hate thing, and you might want to try both out to see which suits you better.

Posted: July 16, 2013
												This game is pretty fun!You play as a godly snake-thing called ''The Breath'' summoned by tribes of little masked people to guide them through the dangers of nature and into new lands after their ''Ancients''.The language they speak in is quite charming, the story they tell is good, the AI is generally good although the path finding can be finnicky at times, and the physics are simply AMAZING.Moving around lava, water and earth is fun to do and the puzzles you solve with it are challenging, but not overly so.Lastly, the natural disasters some levels harbor and the way your tribes counter them if you did your job correctly are a sight to behold (and hear).All in all, this game is completely worth it.

Posted: January 27, 2016
												Seems alot cooler than it really is, extremely lackluster. 45% recommended 55% not Before I bought it, I originally thought it was a god sim, but all you do is pick up a small amount of 1 of the 3 kinds of  elements (water,sand,lava) and drop it somewhere else. Such as picking up sand to block a wall of water, or sucking up some water so the uncontrollable villagers can make an uncontrollable village. Basic Gameplay: Once you make it safe, they will create this little outpost that generally gives you some kind of element manipulation buff such as evaporating all the water on the map. The outposts dont change at all. They only have to be protected from the elements. Your objective on every mission is to inhabit every outpost to proceed. Each mission has some sort of unique obstacle that sometimes requires thought to beat. Inbetween these missions you are  rewatching the same cinematic over and over. Thinking about it, it feels like an antfarm sim because you move elements around while you watch the ants do their own thing. Missions are easy. It is a good idea, 'meh' execution. Price should be somewhere around $10, $15 is steep. Pick it up on sale. One of those games that I dont regret playing, but should've passed on.

Posted: April 18, 2014
Changes your visionFrom Dust contains great part of the world vision used by mankind to explain its surroundings in pre-christian era: the spoken tradition. Hidden within its storyline and in the bonus tales unlocked, one is able to understand how some of our ancestors saw the world and how they believed they could control it: how their traditions of music and ritual kept their minds tranquil against the perils of natural catastrophe and wild dangers.Not only that, the game is work of art, comprising beautifully executed music, masterful narrative and astonishing visuals, all capable of arousing a sense of longing, of belonging to that ancient past.

Posted: December 1, 2015
												I FIXED IT!To everyone that keeps saying that Uplay crashes and that you can't play this is what you need to do:1) Uninstall the game and Uplay (AKA Ubisoft Launcher)2) Install Uplay from Ubisoft's site.3) Login with your account (on Uplay) and make sure you're online.3.1) There is an option to activate game, choose it.3.2) Copy the game's activation code to it (the one Steam provides you)3.3) It will ask you if you want to activate From Dust to that account, choose yes.4) In Uplay, choose "Go Offline", and that's it (but don't close Uplay).6) Install the game on Steam and playNote: In Uplay's settings I recommend that you choose "Always start Offline" and disable any synchronization to Uplay (specially the save files), because it is absolute garbage, you should also disable overlay.For those wondering, the problem is the interaction between Steam and Uplay, and the fix is launching (and installing) Uplay by itself instead of letting Steam do it.The game itself is a lot of fun, it sucks that Ubisoft had to ruin it, I would recommend the game, but not the company.

Posted: August 16, 2015
												Summary: From Dust is an excellent gaming experiment of sorts that cycles back on itself with its brief yet enjoyable campagin.  You play the rold of a god-esque figure that controls the elements and minimally commands your tribe to do tasks (just some simple "go here and go there".  The gameplay is fairly simple at the core though in later levels there is more thinking and fast adjusting/reacting required to ensure the tribes survival.  The learning curve is fairly steady as it adds elements or powers into the mix but I will say near the last level is a bit of a jump in dificulty compared to previous levels.   Graphics:  This game came out 4 years ago from writing this (Aug 17, 2011) and the charm and style still holds up strong.  The dynamic effects are convincing and the character design is interesting.  I do wish they had more animals that appeared to diversify the map but since this is a fairly minimalist game it works as is.  Ocasionally the tsunami effect would catch my attention because of a steap drop off or rise in the water that looked bizarre like a wall of water instead a wave but it is what it is.  Gameplay: Simple and intuitive (played with a xbox 360 controller-needed to be enabled in settings each time)  mainly you are just picking up and putting down materials (sand, water or lava, ocasionally plants or totems as well)  The game is a lightly guided sandbox of sorts where you sculpt the land by changing the flow of rivers and lava flows in order to help a tribe of people reach the exit to the level, this must be unlocked by building all of the villiages on the map which are placed on totem locations.  The level design is spot on with these totems being placed in locations that require you to use different elements and tasks to navigate your tribe but the downside is the AI for these tribe members sometimes cripples gameplay.  I encountered them all to offten crying for help because they weren't satisfied with a path to take or a height difference near them requiring some extra sand raising or lowering until satisfaction.   These poor tribesmen (and women) would also freeze up in terror next to flowing water or lava instead of trying to avoid it which often lead to their demise.Story:There isn't a strong narrative here, essentially the tribe is wondering through different areas/realms with the story cycling back on itself toward the ened.  I will give them kudos for making it work though since the focus here really is just the sandbox gameplay and the minimal aproach they took works fine.  Note:Many slam this game for Uplay issues, I don't think this is fair because Uplay isn't the game.  I am not a fan of running through steam to run through Uplay but it just is what it is, the artists and creatives that shelled out heart and soul into this game created something worth experiencing so don't let the game industry politics soil it for you.

Posted: June 12, 2013
												I really like the idea of this game but it has graphical and longevity issues.First off the textures are beyond bad on this game. It's like looking at a 640x480 game zoomed in to a 50'' screen, that's how bad it is, so it will be really noticeable if you look attently (fortunately you don't have to play a lot of time, it's short), that being said it's a straight up port from the consoles.The game concept is really interesting, but it's really simple, for a god game if you have almost no power at all over the world. Basically controlling the "forces of nature" (lava/water/land) around your island, e.g. building natural barriers to block tsunamis/volcano eruptions, creating bridges to block rivers.It has a simple campaign format where you play maps with an increased number of powers each, but there's not much of a change in between each, and almost no interest to move on.After a while it just gets old and tiring and the lack of good sandbox game features make it pretty stale, I'd say get it if you like the idea of the game, which is pretty much terraforming an island, but don't expect a sandbox game like black&white.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												Beautiful little game that's got some fantastic mechanics here. The only problems are Uplay and the length. I believe the problems with Uplay that meant that this game couldn't be launched have now been fixed (at least, I've never had any issues since I bought it), so that's something.The gameplay is essentially a puzzle-based god game, where you control the elements earth, lava and water and are able to give basic directions to a handful of villagers in order to help your tribe survive. Levels generally focus on one or two problems building up - an incoming flood, or an impending volcanic eruption - and require you to take action to protect your village from the same.The game is, though, far too short. It feels more like a tutorial campaign. What little is there is very nice, with great music and atmosphere. If in future the mechanic is expanded upon, that's something I'd definitely pick up. For now, this is a great game that's on sale often enough, and is definitely worth a shot when it's at about half the asking price.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												Though I only have some 22 hours in on this game it's still one of my all time favorites. It is challenging at times, but also greatly amusing taking sand for instance until there's only rock left underneath then depositing it somewhere else maybe to change the flow of a river or taking water and dumpinjg it somewhere then watching it splash and flow as real water would. This game is very unique in that I've never played another game like it. The graphics are gorgeous as are the effects.My only complaints is that there isnt a sandbox mode(or at least wasnt the last time I played) which I think would be more entertaining than levels with an end goal. I also think it would be cool if they would have more of a society or city building aspect that you would then have to protect from the elements (There are villagers you have to protect, but their society doesnt develop much past small villages). Finally I'll say that while I like this game I would definitely wait until it's on sale because while it is worth buying it's not worth $15 especially considering I got frustrated with it after 22 hours ($15 dollars to me should give a person at least 96 hours worth). Though if you like a challenging game that will get you frustrated to the point where you have to take a break (like old school games from when I was a kid) only to come back with a new strategy and beat the level then you'll like this game. I personally prefer more relaxing, less challenging games, but there simply isnt any other game like this.Still it's a great game if you're a connoisseur!

Posted: May 22, 2013
												From Dust (  ) was on sale on Steam the other day and it looked interesting enough to pick up for $5 and so far I’m really enjoying the chance to play around with dirt and water without getting gunk under my nails.Some levels have you rushing to accomplish things in a hurry under a time limit, but most (so far) seem to allow one to play around at one’s leisure. I love making rivers and helping the plants grow across the maps. The tribal lore is interesting too, I rather like the tales of the plants and animals.On the down side, the levels load before the dramatic entry music finishes, creating a jarring moment where it should have been a nice fanfare entry, and one can’t interact much with the tribespeople. I’m wondering if the loading time music cutoff is because I've got it installed on an SSD and it might behave better on a traditional (slower-loading) platter drive.These are relatively minor though. It’s really about playing with the landscape like a helpful, mysterious deity. If you, like me, enjoyed spending hours playing with dirt and water as a child, you might rather dig From Dust.

												From Dust is an entertaining game that stands out from similar civilization-type games in that you have to craft the land to assist and protect your native people as they go from increasingly inhospitable locations in an effort to find their Ancients who created their world. The story is basic (and not the focus of the game) and there are no real characters besides your virtually identical-looking natives and the only narrative is that which you hear at the begining of each stage. However the voice-over does stand out as it is spoken in a Bahasa Indonesian language that is neat to listen to and don't worry, there are subtitles in English.The real fun comes from the gameplay where you gather up sand, lava, water and more in an effort to keep your people alive and help them to build and maintain their villages in ridiculously dangerous environments such as within the crater of an active volcano, hot damn! These scenarios can defintely be challenging as you will be forced to stop and think in order to plan the best course of terrain alteration or disaster will befall your villagers and you'll be forced to re-examine your strategy or even re-start the stage.I also have to point out the level of realism attached to the various elements in that lava flows like you'd expect, water from tsunamis flows down from elevated portions of the land to pool in recesses, etc. Thanks to this you'll really feel like you're crafting a believable world and perhaps even learn to appreciate how difficult it must be for certain people (both past and present) to struggle against the elements.8/10
